heading: at home to redo earnings
subheading: after discussions with the securities and exchange commission, broadband internet provider at home will restate its earnings to better reflect a 1997 cable deal.
author: wired news report
text: share of at home fell early tuesday after the high-speed internet access provider agreed to restate its earnings -- the company is spreading out a big charge it took to more accurately reflect its business activity. the securities and exchange commission in the past year has been taking a tougher stance against technology companies that take huge, one-time charges to account for acquisitions or marketing deals.following a discussion with the sec, at home (athm) will restate its earnings for past quarters to better reflect a us$247 million deal that took place with cablevision in 1997, according to a wall street journal report.to reflect that deal —- which gave cablevision the rights to purchase 11 million shares of at home stock at 50 cents a share in return for making its cable systems available to at home —- the company took charges of $172.6 million against earnings in the fourth quarter of 1997 and $74.5 million against earnings in the first quarter of 1998.at home said it will reverse those charges and amortize the entire $247.1 million over 57 months, the journal said.at home shares fell $9.88, or 8.1 percent, to $112 in early nasdaq trading.sec officials wouldn't comment on whether or not there were discussions with at home. at home officials weren't immediately available for comment.the exact amount of the restated results will be reported on 20 january with the company's annual results for 1998. for the nine months ending september 1998, revenues totaled $28.8 million, up from $3.7 million in the same period of 1997. net loss totaled $115.8 million, up from $34.7 million in the same period of the year before.
